groups_data.description: Cockroaches (order Blattodea) are related to mantises and termites. They can be found in decaying leaves, soil, and under logs.
groups_data.label: Cockroaches

groups_data.description: Beetles (order Coleoptera) can be recognised by their hard, armor-like wing covers and are found in many habitats.
groups_data.label: Beetles

groups_data.description: Flies (Order Diptera) can be recognised by their proboscoid mouthparts and two translucent wings (not four wings like most flying insects).
groups_data.label: Flies

groups_data.description: Mayflies (order Ephemeroptera) spend most of their lives as aquatic nymphs, emerging en masse for a brief adult life of mating and ovipositing. Can be recognised by their large, triangular, membranous wings and long, trailing "tails" (cerci).
groups_data.label: Mayflies

groups_data.description: True bugs (order Hemiptera) include most plant-feeding insects with piercing, sucking mouthparts. Common true bugs include aphids, planthoppers, scale insects, and cicadas.
groups_data.label: True bugs

groups_data.description: Bees, wasps and ants (order Hymenoptera) can typically be recognised by their slender, constricted waist and tendency to live in social groups, although some families (e.g. sawflies) lack the "wasp waist".
groups_data.label: Bees, wasps & ants

groups_data.description: Moths and butterflies (order Lepidoptera) can be recognised by their broad, powdery wings and tubelike mouthparts.
groups_data.label: Moths & butterflies

groups_data.description: Scorpionflies (order Mecoptera) are unusual insects with four clear, membranous wings, long faces, and curving, pointed genitalia that resemble the stinger of a scorpion.
groups_data.label: Scorpionflies

groups_data.description: Lacewings and mantisflies (order Neuroptera) can be recognised by their clear, membranous wings with an intricate, lace-like venation.
groups_data.label: Lacewings & mantisflies

groups_data.description: Dragonflies and damselflies (order Odonata) develop as aquatic nymphs in freshwater habitats before emerging as ferociously predatory adults. Adult odonates can be recognised by their long, slender bodies, extremely large eyes, and four long, membranous wings of roughly the same size.
groups_data.label: Dragonflies & damselflies

groups_data.description: Crickets and grasshoppers (order Orthoptera) can be recognised by their flat-folded wings (if present) and enlarged hindlegs. Usually found in grass, low shrubs, or on the ground.
groups_data.label: Grasshoppers, crickets, & katydids

groups_data.description: Stick insects (order Phasmida or Phasmatodea) are long, slender insects that specialize in mimicking leaves and twigs. When not moving, these insects are extremely difficult to spot.
groups_data.label: Stick insects

groups_data.description: Stoneflies (order Plecoptera) develop in freshwater habitats like mayflies, but possess abdominal gills (as nymphs) and hold their patterned wings flat against the body (as adults).
groups_data.label: Stoneflies

species_data.description: These cockroaches are difficult to spot, with brown, flattened bodies that blend in well with bark. Females are wingless, while males are winged. Both sexes live under bark, where they feed on decaying wood.
species_data.label: Bark cockroach
species_data.searchText: Bark cockroach Laxta granicollis  Cockroaches

species_data.description: This species is one of Australia's larger cockroaches, and often found in the damp soil beneath rotting logs. Members of this genus are easily recognised by their large, spiny legs.
species_data.label: Australian woodland cockroach
species_data.searchText: Australian woodland cockroach Panesthia australis  Cockroaches

species_data.description: These large, glossy, wingless cockroaches are often found in fallen tree back and leaf litter.
species_data.label: Black woodland cockroach
species_data.searchText: Black woodland cockroach Platyzosteria melanaria  Cockroaches

species_data.description: This shimmering green flightless cockroach is one of the most charismatic insects of the Australian Alps. Both sexes of this species are wingless.
species_data.label: Alpine metallic cockroach
species_data.searchText: Alpine metallic cockroach Polyzosteria viridissima  Cockroaches

species_data.description: The genus Rhinotia and other belid weevils are called "primitive" because they lack the elbowed antennae and other specialized features of the "higher" weevils. Rhinotia is easily recognised by its long, narrow, pointed body with vivid white stripes along the underside.
species_data.label: Primitive weevils
species_data.searchText: Primitive weevils Rhinotia  Beetles

species_data.description: Like other species in the family Buprestidae, these large beetles are brightly coloured and can often be seen perching on leaves. These beetles are also known as "borers" for their laval habit of boring tunnels through the sapwood of trees and shrubs.
species_data.label: Jewel beetles
species_data.searchText: Jewel beetles Castiarina  Beetles

species_data.description: This striking green-and-yellow beetle is most often spotted in the early spring, when mating pairs appear in vast swarms on buildings, vegetation, and other surfaces throughout Southeastern Australia. Despite its name, the soldier beetle does not bite; it does, however, exude a foul-tasting defensive chemical when threatened.
species_data.label: Plague soldier beetle
species_data.searchText: Plague soldier beetle Chauliognathus lugubris  Beetles

species_data.description: Like other members of the family Carabidae, these large, black beetles are fast-moving predators of other small arthropods. As their name suggests, ground beetles can often be found on or in the soil, usually under stones or logs.
species_data.label: Ground beetle
species_data.searchText: Ground beetle Percolestus blackburni  Beetles

species_data.description: These small, extremely glossy black beetles are predatory and often found in damp leaf litter at high elevations throughout New South Wales and Victoria.
species_data.label: Shining ground beetles
species_data.searchText: Shining ground beetles Pseudagonica  Beetles

species_data.description: New South Wales is home to many species of these large, dome-shaped leaf beetles. Paropsines, like all leaf beetles, can be recognised by their wide, flattened feet (for gripping leaf surfaces) and prominent, jellybean-shaped eyes. All Paropsis species feed exclusively on eucalyptus leaves.
species_data.label: Eucalyptus leaf beetles
species_data.searchText: Eucalyptus leaf beetles Paropsis  Beetles

species_data.description: The most frequently spotted ladybird beetles are members of the subfamily Coccinellinae, which are typically medium-sized and dome-shaped, with bright red, black, and/or yellow colouration. These "warning colours" tell predators that the beetles are noxious and foul-tasting.
species_data.label: Ladybird beetles
species_data.searchText: Ladybird beetles Family Coccinellidae  Beetles

species_data.description: Most broad-nosed weevils can be recognised, as their name suggests, by the wide rostrum, elbowed antennae, and scale-covered bodies. Members of the genus Adelognatha are particularly large and slow-moving, and usually found near vegetation.
species_data.label: Broad-nosed weevils
species_data.searchText: Broadnosed weevils Adelognatha  Beetles

species_data.description: These long, oval-shaped beetles superficially resemble jewel beetles (family Buprestidae) but can be recognised by their ability to flip or jump by "clicking" a special joint in their thorax.
species_data.label: Click beetles
species_data.searchText: Click beetles Family Elateridae  Beetles

species_data.description: These small beetles feed on fungus and can be recognised by their clubbed antennae and parallel "seams" along the edges of the prothorax. The species Erotendomychus bimaculatus is seldom seen. It is found only in cool, moist, high-elevation habitats in New South Wales and Victoria, where it feeds on fungus in leaf litter and decaying wood.
species_data.label: Handsome fungus beetle
species_data.searchText: Handsome fungus beetle Erotendomychus bimaculatus  Beetles

species_data.description: As their name suggests, these small, elongate beetles are usually spotted on or near flowers, where they feed on pollen or small insects. Like ladybirds and soldier beetles, melyrids are often brightly coloured to warn predators of their foul-tasting defensive chemicals.
species_data.label: Soft-winged flower beetles
species_data.searchText: Softwinged flower beetles Family Melyridae  Beetles

species_data.description: These large, odd-looking beetles can be recognised by their large, delicate, fan-like antennae and pattern of white speckles.
species_data.label: Feather-horned beetles
species_data.searchText: Featherhorned beetles Family Rhipiceridae  Beetles

species_data.description: These widespread, metallic green beetles are voracious feeders, capable of defoliating both native and non-native plants. Several species occur in the Australian Alps.
species_data.label: Green scarab beetles
species_data.searchText: Green scarab beetles Diphucephala  Beetles

species_data.description: These large flies are big-eyed, swift-flying predators of other insects and are often seen resting on leaves or twigs with their freshly-caught prey.
species_data.label: Robber flies, Assassin flies
species_data.searchText: Robber flies Assassin flies Family Asilidae fly Flies fly

species_data.description: Bush flies (also House flies) are among the most common flies in the world, both inside and out of houses. These medium-sized flies are usually black or grey, and do not bite.
species_data.label: Bush fly
species_data.searchText: Bush fly Musca vetustissima flies Flies fly

species_data.description: Hoverflies may mimic wasps with their vivid black and yellow stripes, but these flies do not bite or sting and are usually seen hovering near (or perching on) flowers.
species_data.label: Hoverflies
species_data.searchText: Hoverflies Family Syrphidae fly Flies fly

species_data.description: These large, biting flies, commonly known as horse flies or march flies, are not a popular group among Australian hikers. They can be recognised by their huge, often brightly-coloured triangle-shaped eyes and hairy bodies. There are several species that occur in the mountains, and they are most abundant in the summer.
species_data.label: Horse flies, March flies
species_data.searchText: Horse flies March flies Scaptia fly Flies fly

species_data.description: These small flies are found anywhere near ripe fruit. Alpine species often lay eggs into the seeds of daisies (Asteraceae).
species_data.label: Fruit flies
species_data.searchText: Fruit flies Family Tephritidae fly Flies fly

species_data.description: These large, long-legged flies are conspicuous for their slow-bumbling flight. Larvae are aquatic, developing in fast-moving streams as plump, legless maggots.
species_data.label: Crane flies
species_data.searchText: Crane flies Family Tipulidae fly Flies fly

species_data.description: In high elevation habitats, mayflies of this genus can be recognised by their speckled wings.
species_data.label: Mayfly
species_data.searchText: Mayfly Ameletoides lacusalbiniae flies Mayflies fly

species_data.description: These tiny, plant-feeding bugs are a favorite prey of ladybird beetles and lacewings. Aphids are often found in large groups on their host plant, with many different life stages clustered together. In early spring, it is common to see dead aphids littering the snow. They are blown up to the mountains from surrounding countryside and die on the snow.
species_data.label: Aphids
species_data.searchText: Aphids Family Aphididae  True bugs

species_data.description: Leafhoppers are sometimes difficult to spot, with their flattened, leaf-like wings held like a tent above the body. They are also very small, usually less than 1 cm in length.
species_data.label: Leafhoppers
species_data.searchText: Leafhoppers Family Cicadellidae  True bugs

species_data.description: These insects spend most of their lives underground, feeding from the roots of trees. Cicadas emerge from the soil in summer, moult into adults, and can be heard buzzing loudly from trees and shrubs.
species_data.label: Cicadas
species_data.searchText: Cicadas Family Cicadidae  True bugs

species_data.description: This family of bugs can be recognised by their large, triangular scutellum and flattened, shield-shaped body. True to their name, many species can secrete or spray offensive-smelling chemicals when threatened.
species_data.label: Stink bugs, Shield bugs
species_data.searchText: Stink bugs Shield bugs Family Pentatomidae  True bugs

species_data.description: In the Australian Alps, bees are commonly seen gathering nectar from flowers in spring and summer. At least 22 species of bee occur in the Australian mountains and most feed on several different flowers. Exoneura bicolor is a small native bee that is common in southern parts of mainland Australia, as well as in Tasmania. It is abundant in mountain areas, and is the second most common bee (after the European honey bee) on the Bogong High Plains.
species_data.label: Bicolour xylopine
species_data.searchText: Bicolour xylopine Exoneura bicolor  Bees wasps  ants

species_data.description: These graceful, slender wasps area often seen hunting for other insects to use as provisions for their larvae. Female parasitoid wasps can be recognised by the long, slender ovipositor arising from the tip of the abdomen.
species_data.label: Braconid wasps
species_data.searchText: Braconid wasps Family Braconidae  Bees wasps  ants

species_data.description: These small black ants are highly abundant in the alpine zone throughout the summer. Becoming active soon after the snow melts, they often construct their nests near bogs.
species_data.label: Rainbow ants
species_data.searchText: Rainbow ants Iridomyrmex  Bees wasps  ants

species_data.description: These are Australia's largest and most conspicuous ants, with huge eyes and jaws. Also known as "bull ants," these insects are aggressive hunters and can deliver a painful bite or sting when disturbed.
species_data.label: Jack-jumper ant
species_data.searchText: Jackjumper ant Myrmecia forficata  Bees wasps  ants

species_data.description: As adults, these insects have wasp-like heads and wings but lack the slender, constricted waist characteristic of other Hymenoptera. The caterpillar-like larvae of sawflies are known as "spitfires" and are often found in dense family groups, feeding together on Eucalyptus leaves.
species_data.label: Sawfly
species_data.searchText: Sawfly Pseudoperga lewisii flies Bees wasps  ants

species_data.description: Although these moths are typically drab brown as adults, geometrid caterpillars are easily recognised by their "inching" gait as they travel across vegetation.
species_data.label: Geometer moths
species_data.searchText: Geometer moths Family Geometridae  Moths  butterflies fly

species_data.description: Skipper butterflies can be recognised by their relatively small size, stout bodies, and characteristic "semi-erect" wing posture. The underside of the wing is typically more vividly patterned than the dorsal side.
species_data.label: Grass skippers
species_data.searchText: Grass skippers Anisynta dominula Anisynta monticolae  Moths  butterflies fly

species_data.description: Skipper butterflies can be recognised by their relatively small size, stout bodies, and characteristic "semi-erect" wing posture. The underside of the wing is typically more vividly patterned than the dorsal side.
species_data.label: Alpine Sedge-skipper
species_data.searchText: Alpine Sedgeskipper Oreisplanus munionga  Moths  butterflies fly

species_data.description: These small, delicate butterflies are often blue-winged, but may also be copper-coloured or purple. They can be recognised by their small size, black-and-white banded antennae, and fine white border along the outer edges of the wings. Many species have small eyespots on the underside of the hindwing.
species_data.label: Gossamer-winged butterflies
species_data.searchText: Gossamerwinged butterflies Family Lycaenidae  Moths  butterflies fly

species_data.description: The bogong moth is one of the most iconic and best known of Australia's alpine insects. In spring, the moths migrate en masse from their overwintering habitats in southern Queensland to the mountains where they stay throughout the summer. During summer, adults can be found in huge numbers in rock crevices, where they remain inactive and live off their fat reserves.
species_data.label: Bogong moth
species_data.searchText: Bogong moth Agrotis infusa  Moths  butterflies fly

species_data.description: This alpine butterfly belongs to the family Nymphalidae and can be recognised by its checkerspot wing pattern with both dorsal and ventral eyespots.
species_data.label: Silver Xenica
species_data.searchText: Silver Xenica Oreixenica orichora Oreixenica correae  Moths  butterflies fly

species_data.description: These moths are large, attractive insects with broad, feather-like antennae and usually with conspicuous eyespots on the dorsal side of the wings. Larvae are enormous caterpillars, often found feeding on the leaves of gum trees. This group is not common in the mountains, but the emperor gum moth (Opodiphthera eucalypti) and Helena moth (Opodiphthera helena) are sometimes found in montane woodlands.
species_data.label: Saturniid moths
species_data.searchText: Saturniid moths Family Saturniidae  Moths  butterflies fly

species_data.description: The Notodontidae are a small family of moths found throughout Australia. Although the adult form of these insects is usually a rather drab brown moth, the caterpillars are instantly recognizable for their habit of marching overland in long, single-file "processions". At least nine species occur in the Australian Alps, including Trichiocercus sparshalli. Most adults of this species are white, but can also be light or dark grey. When disturbed, the moths curl up to expose coloured bands along the back of their abdomen.
species_data.label: Long-tailed bombyx
species_data.searchText: Longtailed bombyx Trichiocercus sparshalli  Moths  butterflies fly

species_data.description: These scorpionflies derive their common name from the habit of dangling from vegetation by their hooked feet, waiting to ambush small prey.
species_data.label: Hangingflies
species_data.searchText: Hangingflies Family Bittacidae fly Scorpionflies fly

species_data.description: Mantisflies (family Mantispidae) are small predatory insects with clear, membranous wings and mantis-like forelimbs. These can be distinguished from true mantises (order Mantodea) by their clear wings and much, much smaller size.
species_data.label: Mantisflies
species_data.searchText: Mantisflies Family Mantispidae fly Lacewings  mantisflies fly

species_data.description: These predatory insects are quick fliers with sharp vision. They can usually be seen resting briefly on vegetation near water or patrolling their territory in a loop. The alpine darner is a large insect, growing up to ~10 cm in length. It is restricted to mountain regions of New South Wales and Victoria. Interestingly, although the male of this species was described in 1916, it took nearly 70 years before the female and larvae were described.
species_data.label: Alpine darner
species_data.searchText: Alpine darner Austroaeschna flavomaculata fly Dragonflies  damselflies fly

species_data.description: The common montane grasshopper is common on mountains below 1600 m in New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory. It is less common in Victoria, but can be found on the Bogong High Plains and near Mt Hotham. Males and females have black "knees", which distinguishes them from close relatives, and their colouring ranges from brown to green-brown. Adults can be found between January and May. This species has short wings and cannot fly.
species_data.label: Common montane grasshopper
species_data.searchText: Common montane grasshopper Kosciuscola cognatus  Grasshoppers crickets  katydids

species_data.description: The brown kosciuscola is the least common of the four Kosicuscola species that are found on the mainland. Although it can be found in sub-alpine areas of Victoria, New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory, it usually occurs in low numbers. Males and females are dark brown with black "knees", making them difficult to distinguish from the common montane grasshopper (Kosciuscola cognatus). A thick pale stripe across the top of each wing can usually be used to identify the brown kosciuscola. This species has short wings and cannot fly.
species_data.label: Brown kosciuscola
species_data.searchText: Brown kosciuscola Kosciuscola cuneatus  Grasshoppers crickets  katydids

species_data.description: The common kosciuscola is common in the Australian Capital Territory, New South Wales and northern Victorian mountains, above 1500 m. It is often found together with the alpine thermocolour grasshopper, but is easily distinguished from that species by its grassy-green colour and two yellow stripes that run down its head and back. Adults are often found in high densitites between February and May. This species has short wings and cannot fly.
species_data.label: Common Kosciuscola
species_data.searchText: Common Kosciuscola  Kosciuscola usitatus  Grasshoppers crickets  katydids

species_data.description: The alpine thermocolour (or chameleon) grasshopper is the most common grasshopper above 1600 m. Males are easily distinguished from other species by their bright blue colour, while the much larger females are mottled brown. The species is found from Mt Baw Baw north to Mt Jagungal and adults occur in high densitites between February and May. Like many mountain grasshoppers, and all of the Kosciuscola, this species has short wings and cannot fly.
species_data.label: Alpine thermocolour grasshopper, Chameleon grasshopper
species_data.searchText: Alpine thermocolour grasshopper Chameleon grasshopper Kosciuscola tristis  Grasshoppers crickets  katydids

species_data.description: Not a lot is known about this grasshopper, which can be found in sub-alpine areas of Victoria and New South Wales. It is found in sub-alpine shrubs, and can sometimes be seen laying eggs on foot tracks. It is a member of the sub-family Catantopinae, the "spur-throated grasshoppers", which are enormously diverse in Australia.
species_data.label: Mountain grasshopper
species_data.searchText: Mountain grasshopper Percassa rugifrons  Grasshoppers crickets  katydids

species_data.description: Although called the wingless grasshopper, many individuals (particularly at low elevations) have wings and can fly. Wingless grasshoppers are widespread throughout Australia and can be found from lowland areas up to around 1800 m.
species_data.label: Wingless grasshopper
species_data.searchText: Wingless grasshopper Phaulacridium vittatum  Grasshoppers crickets  katydids

species_data.description: These small, black, crickets are common in the Australian Alps. They are usually found in grassland and are very active on sunny days. They are small (7-9 mm), so keep a sharp eye out for them. Like most crickets, male Bobilla "chirp" by rubbing their wings together. At least three species of Bobilla live in the Australian Alps (B. victoriae, B. gullanae, and B. plurampe) but they are virtually indistinguishable in the field.
species_data.label: Grassland pygmy cricket
species_data.searchText: Grassland pygmy cricket Bobilla  Grasshoppers crickets  katydids

species_data.description: The mountain spotted grasshopper is an easily identified species with its black body and yellow or white spots. This species makes its own anti-freeze, allowing it to survive cold alpine winters and be among the first insects to emerge after the snow melts. This species has short wings and cannot fly.
species_data.label: Mountain spotted grasshopper
species_data.searchText: Mountain spotted grasshopper Monistria concinna  Grasshoppers crickets  katydids

species_data.description: Also called the "alpine grasshopper", this charismatic species is highly recognisable. When startled, they lift their wings to reveal a bright, red-and-blue striped abdomen. Males have long wings and can often be found basking on their sides in the sun. They produce a buzzing sound by rubbing their wings together. They are common above 1500 m in snowgum understory, but can also be found at lower elevations.
species_data.label: Mountain katydid
species_data.searchText: Mountain katydid Acripeza reticulata  Grasshoppers crickets  katydids

species_data.description: This katydid is common below the treeline, particularly in and around low shrubs. It is darkly coloured and has a distinctive jerking motion when it jumps. Unlike many katydids, it is not predaceous and instead eats flowers, seeds, and grass. The only species in the Austrodectes genus, A. monticolus is also the only Australian member of the katydid sub-family Tettigoniinae to occur at high elevation.
species_data.label: Alpine katydid, Australian shield-back
species_data.searchText: Alpine katydid Australian shieldback Austrodectes monticolus  Grasshoppers crickets  katydids

species_data.description: Stick insects are long, slender insects that specialize in mimicking leaves and twigs. When not moving, these insects are extremely difficult to spot. In the Alps, stick insects are rare.
species_data.label: Stick insects
species_data.searchText: Stick insects Family Phasmatidae  Stick insects

species_data.description: Stoneflies develop in freshwater habitats like mayflies, but possess abdominal gills (as nymphs) and hold their patterned wings flat against the body (as adults). This species is found in both mountain and lowland areas of New South Wales and Victoria.
species_data.label: Stonefly
species_data.searchText: Stonefly Eusthenia venosa flies Stoneflies fly

species_data.description: Tinzeda is a classic leaf mimic, a camouflage strategy common among katydids around the world. They can be recognised by their characteristic white wing stripes that resemble leaf veins. Two species of Tinzeda, T. soror (Kosciuszko tinzeda) and T. albosignata (Stout tinzeda) occur in the Australian Alps, often together, and are difficult to tell apart. Both males and females are long-winged and able to fly and they are usually encountered in shrubbery in the sub-alpine zone.
species_data.label: Kosciuszko tinzeda, Stout tinzeda
species_data.searchText: Kosciuszko tinzeda Stout tinzeda Tinzeda soror Tinzeda albosignata  Grasshoppers crickets  katydids

species_data.description: The European honey bee is the most common and widely distributed of all bees. It is a generalist and can be found on a wide range of native and non-native flower species. It has only recently been recorded in the Australian Alps but is now very common across the Bogong High Plains.
species_data.label: European honey bee
species_data.searchText: European honey bee Apis mellifera  Bees wasps  ants

species_data.description: These tiny flies (usually < 5 mm) are common but easily missed. Not much is known about their ecology but, in the mountains, they are often found on alpine daisies.
species_data.label: Frit flies, Grass flies
species_data.searchText: Frit flies Grass flies Family Chloropidae fly Flies fly

species_data.description: The Noctuidae are a large family of moths that includes a wide diversity of species, some drab brown or grey, and some brightly coloured. The caterpillar stage of P. tristifica is strikingly coloured, with a black and white checkered pattern and an orange head and rump. Adult moths have a wing span of ~4 cm. This species occurs throughout southeastern Australia.
species_data.label: Owlet moth
species_data.searchText: Owlet moth Phalaenoides tristifica  Moths  butterflies fly

species_data.description: The endangered Alpine Stonefly is found only on the Bogong High Plains in Victoria and is known from only 12 sites within this region. Nymphs are usually found in narrow, stony streams, while adults live in nearby rocks and vegetation. The species is long-lived, spending approximately three years developing to the adult stage. Adults emerge between February and May each year, and live for only two months. The largest of Australia's stoneflies, the nymphs are also the top insect predators in streams and eat a variety of both plant and animal material.
species_data.label: Alpine stonefly
species_data.searchText: Alpine stonefly Thaumatoperla alpina flies Stoneflies fly

species_data.description: These peculiar moths are often encountered as caterpillars, when they construct and live in a "bag" of twigs, leaf fragments, or pine needles. Adults are hairy, drab, and rather disheveled in appearance; in many species, adult females are soft-bodied and completely wingless. The alpine case moth is one of two species (the other being the alpine swift moth/grass grub) often blamed for large-scale damage to snowgrass (Poa spp.).
species_data.label: Alpine case moth
species_data.searchText: Alpine case moth Lomera caespitosae  Moths  butterflies fly
